posts.name: James
posts.cooked:
Hi Chief Delphi,

this year our team is building an arm similar to the Unqualified Quokkas. We are using neos and a through bore encoder for rotation. As expected, our arm drifts down after rotating to angles so we want to include some PID control. Any suggestions? I know the sparkPIDcontroller class is what I want to use but I don’t fully understand how .setReference() works. Also is it worth diving into feedforward control to compensate for the gravity, or is PID enough?

Thanks!

So the .setReference() method is how you set your setpoint for the Sparks onboard PID controller. This will work after you’ve setup your PID gains, and is in units based on how you configure the encoder (default is rotations/rps). If you have any weight at the end of your arm then it’s probably a good idea to look into feedforward. The .setReference() method has an optional parameter to add an arbitrary feedforward voltage from one of the WPILib feedforward controllers.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
You might want to consider using limit switches – if not, be very careful when you are first trying things out!

An approach that works well is to do the PID on the RIO – it’s easy to add in feedforward for gravity, put in ranges where things slow down as you approach the limits, etc.  Either way, you probably want to use some form of motion profiling, i.e. ProfiledPIDController on the RIO or Smart Motion on the SPARK MAX.  If you have enough control authority (low enough gearing) and use motion profiling, you may be able to get away without feedforward.  If not, you will probably need this, and it will likely need to be a function of your arm’s angle.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: how are you rotating to an angle in the first place, if not with a feedback loop?

posts.name: James
posts.cooked: We wrote code to get the encoder value and if it is higher or lower than the current position we rotate until we hit that value based on a button press. The problem is our arm slowly starts to drift down out of its position.

posts.name: James
posts.cooked: How does smart motion work? I thought I just wanted to get the PID Contoller on the SparkMax and rotate based off of that.

posts.name: James
posts.cooked: We also have a motor following another (2 neos controlling the arm), do I only need to set these pid values to the leader and the follower motor will just do it? Or do I have to do this for both?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Do not use SmartMotion.  It is inappropriate for position control.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
See this thread: Understanding and Tuning Smart Motion for an arm .  There are recommendations there for not using the SPARK MAX for this, but using the RIO.  I only really have experience using the RIO, so I don’t have an informed opinion on this.  But, I like that you have more visibility and control over things on the RIO.

Using a follower motor should work no matter how the leader motor is getting to the position.

link_counts.title: Understanding and Tuning Smart Motion for an arm

posts.name: James
posts.cooked: What do you suggest I do? We have our through bore encoder connected to our leader spark max. How do we use SparkPIDController and get the absolute encoder?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
I’d use combined feedforward-feedback control.  It does not matter much whether you do it on the RIO or on the motor controller to start.

Read: Tuning a Vertical Arm Position Controller — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

link_counts.title: Tuning a Vertical Arm Position Controller — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: James
posts.cooked: The SparkMaxPIDContoller is the integrated encoder in neo, but we have the through bore encoder attached to he front facing set of pins. How do I get this encoder and use it for PID instead of the encoder built into the neo?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Plug it into a pair of DIO ports on the RIO and use the WPILib Encoder class.  Alternatively, consult the REV documentation for how their onboard position control works.
